Mesoporous supports with metal incorporation have emerged as productive heterogeneous catalysts with high conversion/selectivity in organic synthesis and biomass conversion. In the present work, niobium incorporated mesoporous materials (Nb-MCM-41) has been fabricated with different Si/Nb (33 and 64) ratios by hydrothermal method followed by calcination. The solid Nb-MCM-41 catalysts were characterized to study crystal structure, stability, porosity and acidity by X-Ray diffraction analysis (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), N2 adsorption-desorption, and ammonia-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The prepared catalysts were employed in the oxidation of model biomass intermediate 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). The Nb-MCM-41 (64) solid catalyst was highly efficient with high HMF conversion and selectivity of 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF). The total acidity and prevailing oxidative active sites of niobium species over MCM-41 plays a vital catalytic role in the oxidation of HMF. Altogether, a versatile catalytic system has been proposed with higher life span on recyclability that can be regenerated after longer runs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords 5-Hydroxy methyl furfural Nb-MCM-41 Selective oxidation 2,5-Diformylfuran 1 Introduction Growing demand for fossil reserves has created immense interest to find promising green renewable sources as sustainable alternatives [1,2]. The major and abundant renewable resource is biomass, which suppresses huge amounts of energy and can be turned into a variety of value-added chemicals and fuels with suitable reaction pathways [3–9]. In the long run, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) have been considered as a ‘bio-boon’ for its plethora of platform chemicals those it can produce [10,11]. More importantly, biomass-derived HMF has fascinated much interest for the production of value-based chemicals with sophisticated methodologies. In this scenario, as an important bio-based platform chemical, HMF can be converted to various high value-added products through various reactions, including hydrogenation, oxidation, and hydration [12,13]. HMF molecules can be readily oxidized to produce valued chemicals like 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-(hydroxymethyl) furan-2-carboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formylfuran-2-carboxlic acid (FFCA) and 2,5- furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [14,15]. In particular, selective oxidation of HMF to DFF is imperative since it acts as a precursor in the synthesis of commercially important fine chemicals, drugs, fungicides and functional polymers [16–22]. In general, DFF is produced by homogeneous catalysts under conventional industrial techniques [23–27]. Practically, production of DFF from HMF tend to be a subtle task in a way that the unsaturated aldehyde group present in HMF is reactive to form other intermediates. To overcome this, various catalysts have been proposed to find the suitable reaction path and predict the synthesis conditions contributing to DFF selectivity. Utilization of solid acid/base catalysts with excellent catalytic activity for the production of various organic derivatives has been extensively put forth. For the past two decades, heterogeneous catalysts have been explored for their potential catalytic features such as recyclable, eco-friendliness, less corrosiveness along with efficient conversion of the reactants and high product yield [28–30]. A variety of solid catalysts has been reported to possess remarkable efficiency towards biomass conversion [10,31–33]. Moreover, transition metal supported catalysts find its prime place due to the tunable acidity or basicity with diverse oxygen species that are prevalent within the heterogeneous support. Such novel characteristics with redox properties are vital in achieving catalytic efficiency. Amid plenty of studies on HMF oxidation to DFF, metal supported heterogeneous catalysts involving vanadium [34,35], ruthenium [36–39], manganese [40–43], and other poly-metal catalysts [44–47] showed significant interest to comprehend selective mechanistic path. Among various metals, niobium species are profound with acidic, water tolerant and specifically mild oxidative properties. [48,49]. To our knowledge, Nb based catalysts have rarely been studied over HMF oxidation to yield different products and not confined toward DFF. For instance, very recently poly metal (Co, Mn or Fe) combined Nb silica mesoporous cores have been employed for HMF oxidation to synthesize FDCA. [50]. Henceforth, in designing a catalytic system for the oxidation of HMF, mild oxidation would be a principal choice and this could be achieved with such Nb oxides over heterogeneous supports. Furthermore, it has been evidenced that the local structure of Nb highly depend on the nature of precursors employed, synthesis method, and the support on which it is incorporated providing room for novel structural active sites and catalytic activity [50,51]. In addition, mesoporous supports has been widely studied due to its porosity, metal incorporation viability, high thermal stability, large surface area and controlled acidic properties. Subsequently, from the industrial point of view, developing an efficient, recyclable, selective, and stable catalyst for HMF oxidation is still challenging. Based on the state of art, herein we report the synthesis and efficiency of Nb-MCM-41 catalysts with tunable porosity and acidity over the oxidation of HMF to DFF under liquid phase conditions. The mesoporous catalysts demonstrated higher efficiency involving excellent conversion and selectivity toward DFF. The optimization of reaction parameters (catalyst amount, solvent, temperature and time) and catalyst reusability are performed. The mesoporous structure with high surface area allows the HMF molecule to diffuse in and out of the wide porous channels containing Nb species along with the moderate acidity and mild oxidative property. Such a well-comprised resourceful catalysts would prove as a potential candidate for the production of platform chemicals from biomass intermediates. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods Fumed silica, niobium oxalate, cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), tetra methyl ammonium hydroxide, t‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) and other chemicals used in the investigation were of analytical grade (Alfa Aesar™). Reactant and standards such as HMF, DFF, FFCA, HMFCA and FDCA were procured from Sigma–Aldrich. All the reagents were used as such without any further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of Nb-MCM-41 catalysts MCM-41 and Nb-MCM-41 materials were prepared according to a modified procedure reported previously [52]. Niobium oxalate and fumed silica were used as niobium and silicon sources, respectively and CTAB was used as the surfactant. TMAOH was added to 15 ml H2O and stirred for 10 min. 1/3rd fumed silica was slowly added to this and stirred for 20 min (solution A). 6.56 g of CTAB was dissolved in 40 ml H2O slowly (without foam formation). To this 0.7 g NaOH in 17 ml H2O was added and stirred for 30 min (solution B). The solution A was added to solution B, followed by the addition of appropriate amount of niobium oxalate (for Si/Nb = 60 and/or 30) in 0.1 M oxalic acid and the mixture was stirred for 1 h. Remaining fumed silica was added to this, stirred for another 1 h. The pH of the gel was adjusted to 11 and the mixture was subjected to hydrothermal treatment at 100 °C for 24 h. After crystallization, the resultant product was filtered, washed, dried and calcined at 550 °C for 1 h in nitrogen atmosphere followed by 5 h in air at a heating rate of 1 °C per min. The resulting sample was designated as Nb-MCM-41 (64) and Nb-MCM-41 (33) representing final calcined product with respective Si/Nb ratio (Table 1 ). 2.3 Characterization of catalysts Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on a Rigaku Miniflex II powder X-ray diffractometer with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å) operating at 30 kV and 15 mA. Diffraction patterns were also recorded using a Bruker D8 Focus Advance diffractometer equipped with LynxEye detector with a Ni-filtered Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Low (0.5 - 8°) diffraction patterns were obtained with a scanning rate of 0.5° - 1° min−1, respectively. The metal composition was analyzed by using the X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) (PANalytical B.V. AXIOSmAX). Nb content was measured using ICP-AES Optima 5300 DV-PerkinElmer equipment. Thermo gravimetric and differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) measurements were carried out on a Perkin Elmer Diamond Thermo gravimetric analyzer. Measurement were carried out in air atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 and an air flowing rate 20 ml min−1. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at 77 K on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 apparatus. The specific surface area of the samples were calculated according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and pore size distribution curves were obtained from the analysis of nitrogen desorption isotherms using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method for mesoporous materials and Horvath–Kawazoe (HK) method for microporous AC. Ammonia-Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II chemisorption analyzer under helium flow (30 mL min−1) with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 up to 400 °C and 15 min. hold time. The desorption profiles were monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to recording the curves the samples were heated to 350 °C (10 °C min−1) and held for 15 min. under flowing helium. TEM characterization was performed using a JEOL 3010 electron microscope operated at 300 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed on an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) multipurpose surface analysis system (Specs™, Germany) employing a conventional X-ray source (XR-50, Specs, Mg Kα, 1253.6 eV). 2.4 Liquid phase oxidation of HMF and product analysis The oxidation of HMF was performed in a 15 mL stainless-steel reactor equipped with an electrical heating jacket. 50 mg of 5-HMF dissolved in 2.5 ml of CH3CN (CH3CN) into a 15 ml sealed tube with TBHP (2 mmol), in which 50 mg of the catalyst was added on stirring with magnetic pellet. Then the sealed tube was kept over a stirrer in an oil bath with required temperature. After the reaction was completed, the products were filtered to remove the catalysts and analyzed by HPLC. HPLC (Agilent Technologies) equipped with photodiode array detectors with C-18 column was employed for the analysis of products. The mobile phase composition was 80:20 CH3CN/water with 0.2% triethylamine, at a flow rate of 0.5 mL min−1. HMF conversion, and selectivity of products were quantified by the following equations on a carbon basis. To obtain reproducible results, each analysis of the liquid products were repeated twice. HMF Conversion ( % ) = [ C ] HM F i − [ C ] HM F f [ C ] HM F i * 100 Product Selectivity ( % ) = [ C ] P r o d u c t [ C ] HM F i − [ C ] HM F f * 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Nb-MCM-41 catalyst characterizations Figs. 1 and 2 depicts the powder XRD pattern of various as-synthesized and calcined Nb-MCM-41 and MCM-41 catalysts. All the as-synthesized and calcined samples of niobium incorporated MCM-41 showed XRD patterns similar to that of pure siliceous MCM-41 with characteristic reflections, viz., 100, 110 and 200 at 2θ = 2.2°, 3.7° and 4.4°, respectively. [53]. This indicates the presence of well-ordered framework with typical mesoporous 2D hexagonal MCM-41 structure. Further, the reflections are shifted to higher angle upon calcination indicating a contraction of unit cell size by the removal of surfactant in addition to the condensation of silanol and niobium hydroxo species. The peaks of Nb-MCM-41 catalysts are shifted to lower angle as compared to that of MCM-41 confirming the incorporation of niobium into the siliceous framework. The calculated unit cell parameter of Nb-MCM-41 is higher than the noibium-free siliceous MCM-41. The increase in unit cell dimension could be attributed to the possible isomorphous substitution of pentavalent niobium to tetravalent silicon owing to the larger crystal radius of the former than the latter. It is also observed that the unit cell parameter of calcined Nb-MCM-41 increases upon increasing niobium content indicating the higher incorporation of niobium into siliceous framework when compared among Nb-MCM-41 (64) and Nb-MCM-41 (33). The elemental composition of Nb-MCM-41 prepared with different Si/Nb mole ratio was determined by XRF and is summarized in Table 1. From the XRF results, it is clear that most of the metal ions are incorporated that from the synthesis gel (initial to final nSi/nNb ratio) of the prepared catalysts. In addition, it could be understood that a part of Si atoms in the synthesis mixture is not involved in the mesostructure formation which supports a preferential incorporation of Nb atoms. Fig. 3 shows the representative TG-DTA thermograms of as-synthesized MCM-41 and Nb-MCM-41 materials. TG-DTA of all as-synthesized samples showed three stages of weight losses which is in good agreement with the literature data available for MCM-41 [54]. The initial weight loss was up to 160 °C which is due to desorption of physisorbed water. Weight loss from 160 to 350 °C is due to the decomposition and desorption of organic template. The minute quantity of weight loss above 350 to 600 °C is related to water loss from the condensation of adjacent silanol groups to form siloxane bonds. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and mesopore size distributions of the samples are shown in Fig. 4 a–c. Textural properties of Nb-MCM-41 are summarized in Table 1. The N2 sorption isotherms of Nb-MCM-41 exhibit reversible type IV isotherms of IUPAC classification with sharp inflection reflecting the uniformity of the pores and the H1-type hysteresis loop exhibited by all the samples indicates the presence of large sized mesopores [55]. The parent MCM-41 shows a surface area of 791 m2/g. The Nb-MCM-41 with Si/Nb: 64 and 33 materials showed the BET surface area as 344 and 280 m2/g respectively. It is evident that Nb-MCM-41 catalysts have lower surface area than that of the pure siliceous samples indicating the incorporation of niobium into the mesoporous silica. Also, on higher Nb concentration, the surface area decreases due to more number of metal species over silica matrix. Moreover, pore size of the Nb-MCM-41 (64) and Nb-MCM-41 (33) catalysts were found to be 41 Å and 44 Å, those higher than that obtained for MCM-41 (39 Å) indicating the alteration occurred due to metal incorporation. Pore volumes of Nb-MCM-41 catalysts were observed to decrease when compared with MCM-41 which could be attributed to the pore filling by metal ions [56]. Total acidity with weak to strong acid sites could be measured by NH3-TPD technique and the corresponding TPD profiles of Nb-MCM-41 and MCM-41 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . In general the desorption temperature of strong acid sites are typically higher from 350 °C, and weak-medium acid sites appear below this temperature [57]. MCM-41 and Nb-MCM-41 catalysts showed broad desorption signals indicative of weak acid sites and the number of weak acid sites were become more pronounced in Nb-MCM-41 catalysts. The intensity of TCD signal of Nb-MCM-41 catalysts is greater than that of MCM-41 and is also increased with the increase of niobium content. This reveals that at higher Nb concentration desorption peak shifted to slightly higher temperature. This is due to the overall increase in concentration as well as strength of acid sites with increasing Nb concentration. The slight acidity of MCM-41 (0.01 mmol/g) is due to the presence of non-condensed silanol groups. Acidity of Nb-MCM-41 (64) and Nb-MCM-41 (33) was observed to be 0.08 mmol/g and 0.1 mmol/g, respectively. TEM image of Nb-MCM-41 (64) shows the mesoporous structure of MCM-41 (Fig. 6 ) and the Nb content is evidenced by ICP-AES result. The Nb content in Nb-MCM-41 (64) was found to be 1.2 wt% and these observations confirm the distribution and presence of Nb in MCM-41 support. Surface chemical composition and binding state of Nb-MCM-41 (64) was analyzed by XPS (Fig. 7 ). The Si 2p spectrum of Nb-MCM-41 (64) is shown in Fig. 7a. The peak centered at binding energies (BE) of 103.4 eV, is assigned to the characteristic of silicates. The spectrum of O 1 s (Fig. 7b) revealed the peak centered at 532.9 eV corresponding to oxygen species in the material, and the oxygen species of Nb could also be observed within the lower range similar to those observed in mesoporous materials [58]. Nb3d spectrum showed two different peaks, characteristic of the Nb3d5/2 (BE = 207.2 eV) and Nb3d3/2 (BE = 210.2 eV) assigned to Nb5+ in Nb2O5 (Fig 7c) [59,60]. 3.2 Catalytic activity of Nb-MCM-41 in HMF oxidation As well explored, HMF is one of the promising biomass derived platform chemical that can be readily oxidized to produce value-added chemicals (mainly: DFF, FFCA, HMFCA, and FDCA) as shown in Scheme 1. According to the literature, the transformation of HMF on oxidation involves complicated reaction routes as monitoring a specific product turn to be challenging [37,61,62]. Here, the catalytic activity of Nb-MCM-41 was evaluated for the oxidation of HMF in liquid phase conditions in the presence of TBHP. The effects of reaction time, reaction temperature, choice of solvent, catalyst feed amount on HMF conversion and DFF yield were precisely investigated. As per the reaction analysis, oxidation of hydroxyl group in HMF alone is needed to be oxidized for the selective oxidation of HMF to DFF without making the aldehyde group being attacked since it is highly reactive. FFCA, HMFCA and FDCA are predominant with the reaction of respective functional groups. In the present reaction conditions, regardless of the temperature, FFCA and HMFCA was formed in less yields over Nb-MCM-41 (64) catalyst at all stages. On the other hand, Nb-MCM-41 (64) was found to be efficient catalyst in DFF selectivity at lower temperatures. Conversion and selectivity over various catalysts are presented in Table 2 . Besides, bulk niobium oxalate and Nb2O5 did not have catalytic activity proving the necessity of the solid active sites associated with mesoporous support for the oxidation reaction. The oxidation reaction over H-Mordenite, and γ-alumina offered lower reaction rates with lower conversion and selectivity. With MCM-41 alone, the reaction did not give products and also without any catalyst, oxidation was observed to be unstable and hesitated to proceed well. The feed of 50 mg catalyst was observed to be best quantity for a given substrate concentration (1 mmol) to offer higher selectivity toward DFF (Fig. 8 a). Increasing the amount to 75 mg of catalyst, DFF selectivity decreased even though conversion was high. This could be attributed to the availability of more concentration of active sites leading to side reactions and over oxidation as the catalyst loading increases. Also, for 25 mg of catalyst, the conversion and selectivity was considerably less due to the lower number of catalytic active sites created by Nb species at the available area over the silica matrix. Such a formation of selective DFF product could be due to the adsorption of OH group in HMF over Nb ions in silica matrix with selective oxidative property without affecting the C=O group. More intense observation about the DFF reactivity is that it leads to form diol intermediate on hydration than that from FFCA [62]. In the present catalytic system, such hydration is avoided to yield DFF as the main product and this is attributed to the moderate acidity. Altogether, it has been contentious about scheming the parameters such as, acidic or basic nature of catalysts, oxidant properties, and temperature would contribute clear mechanistic insight. A plausible mechanism for the HMF oxidation over Nb-MCM-41 catalysts in the presence of TBHP is shown in Scheme 2. DFF is seen as main product whereas FFCA and HMFCA could be regarded as by-products in far lower yields. The mechanism of HMF oxidation could be described on two aspects where DFF possibly pronounced by : 1) the oxidative active sites of Nb-MCM-41 co-ordinates with TBHP creating Nb-peroxide intermediate and, 2) prevailing solid medium acid sites. Based on these two features, promotion of HMF oxidation toward DFF takes place with regeneration of catalyst available for next cycle. For the complex HMF reaction, rehydration could be avoided by weak-medium acidity in this regime. Moreover, in this catalytic approach, high selectivity is also ascribed to easier diffusion through controlled pore size of silica matrix with Nb co-ordinates. In the case of MCM-41 based supports, reactant and product pass through the mesopores without any diffusion or product precipitation that would commonly occur on employing conventional catalysts [63]. The selectivity of DFF was less than 1% in the absence of any catalyst involving the usage of TBHP alone as the oxidant. Hence, the necessity of the catalyst is vital in the HMF oxidation reaction. The effects of different solvents were investigated on the oxidation of HMF and are shown in Fig. 8b. HMF conversion and DFF selectivity was observed to be less in H2O, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and dimethylformamide (DMF) over Nb-MCM-41 with TBHP oxidant. In particular, chance of HMF degradation to form glycolic acid is higher when water is used as solvent [50]. For HMF conversion on present reaction conditions, CH3CN offered higher conversion and selectivity for all experiments. This could be explained due to the availability of catalytic active sites to the reactant substrate in CH3CN with usage of TBHP oxidant without steric hindrance satisfying solvent-reactant priority in organic reactions. Productivity over such solvents is also based on indirect effect that foresee reformed active sites on catalysts [64]. This behavior was further evident from the resultant low conversion (12%) and selectivity (≤ 3%) over Nb2O5 catalyst in CH3CN with the lack of active sites. In addition, the HMF conversion and selectivity to DFF was 43% and 37.9% in aromatic solvent such as toluene. As the use of solvents can directly influence reaction rates, conversion and product selectivity, here the CH3CN acts as building alternate reaction pathway toward selective oxidation. To improve the yield of DFF in CH3CN, optimization of reaction temperature was investigated. The effects of reaction temperature on the oxidation of HMF over Nb MCM-4 (64) with TBHP in CH3CN are showed in Fig. 9 a. The reactions are conducted at 70 °C to 110 °C for a 12 h time period. The HMF conversion and DFF selectivity were 46.2% and 97.7% respectively at 70 °C after 12 h reaction time. FFCA and HMFCA were found as low as 1.4% and 0.9% respectively, at 70 °C. When the reaction time is increased to 90 °C, HMF conversion increases to 93.7% at the same reaction time where DFF selectivity was 99.2% with other by-products FFCA (0.6%) and HMFCA (0.2%). More importantly, HMF oxidation proceeded with less amount of by-product formation which makes the present reaction design and catalyst to be productive. DFF yield subsequently declined and was found to be 81.1% at a conversion of 95.4% respectively when the reaction temperature was further increased to 110 °C. The optimal reaction temperature for synthesis of DFF from HMF oxidation reaction was found to be at 90 °C. As per the obtained results, by-products such as FFCA (16.6%) and HMFCA (0.3%) with other unknown humins were formed at higher reaction temperature of 110 °C due to the over oxidation of HMF. Moreover, DFF is unstable at higher temperatures as it forms other oxide and acid derivatives. From this trend, it is understood that at high temperatures, OH and C=O groups in HMF are largely involved in the reaction to form most diversified oxidation products as witnessed from this catalytic path. Even though, DFF was higher among the oxidation products over Nb-MCM-41(64). However, the present protocol predominantly account for the remarkable DFF selectivity at 70 °C to 90 °C for given optimal reaction conditions. The effect of reaction time on selectivity toward DFF have been investigated in detail. For Nb MCM-4 (64), the effect of different reaction time (1 to 14 h) was studied at constant temperature (70 °C, 90 °C, and 110 °C), individually. The corresponding plots are shown in Fig. 9b-d. From the observation, it was evident that at 70 °C, conversion of HMF increased from 3.6% to 79.4% when the DFF selectivity elevated from 73.4% to 89.7% between 1 h to 12 h. After that DFF selectivity decreased to 88.5% (14 h). At 90 °C, the conversion of HMF tend to increase from 34.6 to 99% (4 to 14 h) where the highest selectivity toward DFF was 99.2% after 12 h. Such a higher DFF selectivity was observed with 93.7% HMF conversion. The prolonged reaction time had direct effect on catalysts to give higher level of byproducts compared to lesser time periods. Also it could be attributed that the formation of DFF decreased at longer reaction time promoting supplementary routes to build byproducts. From the observation, it is evident that the possibility of over oxidation and side reactions are far less at 90 °C for 12 h. At this point, it was interesting to realize that milder oxidation conditions at low temperatures reported here are adequate to serve higher DFF selectivity. For comparison, the HMF oxidation over Nb-MCM-41 (33) was studied at different reaction time period at constant temperature. Product selectivity and conversion on reaction time at different temperatures are presented in Fig. S1a-c. The conversion of HMF increased to 100% (12 h) from 27.8% (4 h) at 110 °C with higher DFF selectivity (67.7%) at 8 h. Thus, the time period was important in determining the product selectivity apart from the conversion statistics. Moreover, DFF was 53.7% at 8 h and 45.4% after 14 h at 90 °C. The selectivity toward DFF over Nb-MCM-41 (33) after 8 h reaction time was 47.1% at 33.7% conversion at 70 °C. At this temperature, DFF selectivity was as high as 52.2% after 12 h for 45.3% HMF conversion, respectively. Thus it could be observed that for reaction times at all temperatures over Nb-MCM-41 (33), the selectivity of the main product were not high single-handedly. Such slow reaction rates could be due to the higher metal content over MCM-41 silica matrix with lower surface area in addition to over-oxidative or slightly higher acidic property compared to Nb-MCM-41 (64). This ensured that Nb-MCM-41 (64) accounts for its higher efficiency to achieve selective oxidation of HMF to DFF. Turn over frequency (TOF) was calculated based on moles of product formed per moles of catalyst active sites and time [65]. TOF value of Nb-MCM-41 (64) was 1.03 (for 12 h) and that of Nb-MCM-41 (33) was 0.84 (for 8 h). Presence of HMFCA could be due to hydroxylation and/or hydrogenation as there would be a change in catalyst behavior after long reaction time. For instance: hydrogenation of DFF to 2,5-di(hydroxymethyl)furan (DHMF) and 2,5-di(hydroxymethyl)tetrahydrofuran (DHMTHF) over various heterogeneous catalysts was patented by M. Ibert et al. recently [66]. Such intermediates (derivatives of HMF) could possibly transform to HMFCA and other by-products. Associated with such reaction intermediates, there is more scope to study the HMF based reaction mechanism in future. The recyclability of the catalyst is significant to be employed in industrial applications. In order to explore the nature of heterogeneity, Nb-MCM-41 (64) catalyst was washed with methanol after the reaction and dried in vacuum oven at 100 °C for 5 h, and then used for the next run. The recyclability results on HMF conversion and DFF selectivity are represented in Fig. 10 . The catalyst was reusable up to five cycles without any serious variation in the selectivity. The porous nature of the reused catalyst (Nb-MCM-41 (64)) was analyzed by N2 sorption technique (Fig. S2). Pore volume and pore diameter was found to be 0.40 cm3/g and 41 Å without any major change in the mesopore properties. The total acidity of the reused catalyst (Nb-MCM-41 (64)) was measured by NH3-TPD spectrum (Fig. S3). After five recycles, the acidity of the catalyst Nb-MCM-41 (64) was found to be 0.078 mmol/g and there is no major variation in the acidity that reasonably offered high DFF selectivity. For all catalytic runs, the activity was found to be efficient demonstrating the potential of the catalyst. 4 Conclusions Nb-MCM41 with its porous feature, acidic nature, and structural parameters was revealed to have a positive impact on the oxidation of HMF thus enhancing its catalytic activity toward high DFF selectivity. The mesoporous catalyst, Nb-MCM-41 (64), offered higher DFF selectivity of about 99.2% at low temperature under optimized reaction conditions. More reasonably, mesopore structure with accessible Nb active sites providing oxidative and acidic properties lead to concurrent pathways of HMF oxidation of 5-HMF to DFF. Other by-products such as FFCA and HMFCA were found to be in small percentage and furthermore, over-oxidation of DFF to FDCA was effusively avoided in all cases over the present catalytic system. The results of recyclability proved that the Nb-MCM41 catalyst possess longer life span for the HMF oxidation reaction. The obtained results support a determined effect of structural and textural features of the Nb supported catalysts upon the mild oxidative conversion of HMF molecules. Such an advancement of solid acid catalysts with pertinent active sites, tunable pores and surface-oxidative property seems to be the successful way to produce selective oxidation products from furan-moiety based biomass compounds. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous supports with metal incorporation have emerged as productive heterogeneous catalysts with high conversion/selectivity in organic synthesis and biomass conversion. In the present work, niobium incorporated mesoporous materials (Nb-MCM-41) has been fabricated with different Si/Nb (33 and 64) ratios by hydrothermal method followed by calcination. The solid Nb-MCM-41 catalysts were characterized to study crystal structure, stability, porosity and acidity by X-Ray diffraction analysis (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), N2 adsorption-desorption, and ammonia-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The prepared catalysts were employed in the oxidation of model biomass intermediate 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). The Nb-MCM-41 (64) solid catalyst was highly efficient with high HMF conversion and selectivity of 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF). The total acidity and prevailing oxidative active sites of niobium species over MCM-41 plays a vital catalytic role in the oxidation of HMF. Altogether, a versatile catalytic system has been proposed with higher life span on recyclability that can be regenerated after longer runs.
coredata.dc:title: Selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-diformylfuran over niobium incorporated MCM-41 catalyst
